content: * *Tanjong Chek Jawa** (or **Tanjung Chek Jawa** or simply **Chek Jawa**) is a [cape](/wiki/Cape_(geography)) and the name of its 100-hectare [wetlands](/wiki/Wetland) located on the south-eastern tip of [Pulau Ubin](/wiki/Pulau_Ubin), an island off the north-eastern coast of the [main island of Singapore](/wiki/Pulau_Ujong). Chek Jawa is among the last few places left in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) with a natural rocky shore. The wetlands are unique as several [ecosystems](/wiki/Ecosystem) can be observed in one area – [sandy](/wiki/Sand) beach, [rocky](/wiki/Rock_(geology)) beach, [seagrass](/wiki/Seagrass) lagoon, [coral](/wiki/Coral) rubble, [mangroves](/wiki/Mangrove) and [coastal](/wiki/Coast) forest. The site forms part of the [Ubin–Khatib Important Bird Area](/wiki/Ubin%E2%80%93Khatib_Important_Bird_Area) (IBA), identified as such by [BirdLife International](/wiki/BirdLife_International) because it supports significant numbers of visiting and resident birds, some of which are [threatened](/wiki/Threatened_species). In December 2001, the government called off reclamation plans of the Chek Jawa area after a biodiversity survey conducted by conservationist volunteers. State use of the land has been deferred indefinitely. ## History ### Preservation Previously virtually unknown, Chek Jawa came into national prominence and focus only since the early 2000s when the area's rich [biodiversity](/wiki/Biodiversity) was discovered almost by chance during a nature outing at [low tide](/wiki/Low_tide). News on the impending [land reclamation](/wiki/Land_reclamation) works planned by the government on the area sparked a rare show of public-led and coordinated effort to reverse the reclamation plans. A group of volunteers, headed by botanist Joseph Lai (who first discovered Chek Jawa's rich ecosystems in December 2000), conducted a biodiversity survey months before the area was to be reclaimed in 2001. This survey was captured on the documentary *[Remember Chek Jawa](/wiki/Remember_Chek_Jawa)* by Eric Lin Youwei. The volunteers then submitted a report and petitioned to the government for the preservation of the natural habitat. The [Singapore Government](/wiki/Singapore_Government), in turn, surprised many when they acceded to these requests in December 2001. They agreed to leave the Chek Jawa area untouched for the next ten years. The area has been fenced off due to an increase of tourists into the area, damaging the ecosystem in the area. [Conservation](/wiki/Habitat_conservation) efforts were made by the [Ministry of National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) to preserve the area. In 2001, the [National Parks Board](/wiki/National_Parks_Board) (NParks) took over Chek Jawa's management. NParks conducts free guided [tours](/wiki/Tour_guide) of Chek Jawa a few times each month during low [spring tide](/wiki/Spring_tide) periods, and about 20,000 visitors have gone on its tours from 2002 to 2007. ### Temporary closure In early 2007, Chek Jawa was closed to the public after being damaged by heavy rains in December 2006. [Freshwater](/wiki/Freshwater) rains upset the wetlands' [saltwater](/wiki/Seawater) balance, resulting in the widespread death of marine creatures such as [sea anemones](/wiki/Sea_anemone), [seastars](/wiki/Seastar), [sponges](/wiki/Sponge). Tours conducted by NParks were stopped in March that year to let the wetlands recover. ### Re-opening and new development Source: On 8 July that year, the nature preserve was re-opened to the public and is free of charge. Visitors going to Chek Jawa no longer need to join the free guided tours conducted by NParks. These are conducted only a few times each month during low spring tide periods. The Singapore Government added new [amenities](/wiki/Amenities) with a visitor management plan for Chek Jawa, at a cost of [S$](/wiki/S$)7 million. These included a 1.1-kilometre [boardwalk](/wiki/Boardwalk), a 20-metre tall viewing [tower](/wiki/Tower) and the [Chek Jawa Visitor Centre](/wiki/Chek_Jawa_Visitor_Centre) with a viewing [jetty](/wiki/Jetty). The boardwalk was built along the coast and into the mangrove area allowing visitors to get up close to plant and marine life such as [fiddler crabs](/wiki/Fiddler_crab) and [monitor lizards](/wiki/Monitor_lizard), without damaging the area. Special care was taken to construct the boardwalk, which is made from concrete but simulated to resemble timber. This is more [environmentally friendly](/wiki/Environmentally_friendly) as it cuts down on the use of wood while still retaining its natural feel. The free seven-story viewing tower called the *Jejawi Tower* allows visitors to view the tree [canopy](/wiki/Canopy_(forest)) and observe [birdlife](/wiki/Birdlife) such as the [collared kingfisher](/wiki/Collared_kingfisher) and [straw-headed bulbul](/wiki/Straw-headed_bulbul). The visitor center, which was converted from a [Tudor-style](/wiki/Tudor_style_architecture) house built in the 1930s, allowed visitors to learn more about Chek Jawa's wildlife. A small trash receptacle and a soda vending machine are available, otherwise the small kiosk style center is typically unmanned. ## Ecological value Chek Jawa is made up of 6 interdependent ecosystems – namely, its coastal forest, [mangrove forest](/wiki/Mangrove_forest), its [rocky shore](/wiki/Rocky_shore), the sandy shore, seagrass lagoon and the coral rubble. Within each of the ecosystems, there is an abundance of natural creatures, rare plants, local and migratory birds. These have attracted photographers, nature lovers, student groups and others to visit Chek Jawa. ## Notes and references - Tan, Ria and Yeo, Alan, in association with The Raffles Museum of Biodiversity Research, The National University of Singapore (2003) *Chek Jawa guidebook* Singapore: Simply Green [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-04-8832-7 - Chua, Ee Kiam (2002) *Chek Jawa: discovering Singapore's biodiversity* Singapore : Simply Green [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-04-6814-8 - National Parks Board – Chek Jawa Archived 19 June 2020 at the [Wayback Machine](/wiki/Wayback_Machine) - The Saga of Tanjong Chek Jawa - Chek Jawa by NUS - Chek Jawa by WildSingapore - Satellite image of Tanjung Chek Jawa – [Google Maps](/wiki/Google_Maps) 01°24′29.06″N 103°59′32.28″E﻿ / ﻿1.4080722°N 103.9923000°E﻿ / 1.4080722; 103.9923000
